parameters.source_text:
The case of Mr A
Mr A is a 72-year-old retired railway conductor who lives with his wife in the house of their 43-year-old daughter and her family. Still active on the family smallholding, he is increasingly frustrated by difficulties in operating machinery and in finding his way about the house. Accompanied by his wife and daughter, he visited Dr B’s clinic for memory disturbance, where he was diagnosed with hypertension, arteriosclerotic occlusive disease, and multiple subcortical perivascular lesions on a computer scan of his brain. The overall diagnosis was subcortical vascular dementia with a moderate degree of impairment. It emerged that Mr A also had considerable impairment of his short-term memory (e.g. telephone numbers) and long-term recall (e.g. names of old friends). However, he denied strenuously that his mental powers were in any way impaired.
In the course of the consultation, Dr B asked Mr A whether he drove a car. Mr A replied that he did, and Dr B warned him that he should stop, from a medical point of view – because of his memory impairment.
Mr A absolutely refused to consider stopping: he was in perfectly good health, he insisted, and still very fit.
'I’m a lot better driver than all those young lunatics!'
Mr A’s daughter interrupted at this point to describe two small car accidents which her father had recently caused. Mr A then announced, out of the blue, that he had just decided to buy a new car. If there was any problem, it lay in the old car, not in his driving.
And there the matter rested, at least in the doctor’s consultation.
Privately Mr A’s wife and daughter agreed between themselves that the only possible solution was to hide the car keys. But Mr A managed to locate them, and drove off to a reunion of his railway colleagues without any incident. When he returned, it was with a new copy of the car keys, and a bad mood that lasted for days at home. Mr A’s wife has now lost any will to prevent her husband from driving: she can’t bear his anger, she says, and in any case he was perfectly all right last time he drove. Perhaps he doesn’t have dementia after all, she remarked to the doctor on her own next visit to his surgery.
(Hope, 1997)

data.vignette: A 72-year-old man is evaluated for worsening forgetfulness and getting lost at home. Imaging and exam support moderate subcortical vascular dementia. He insists his thinking is normal. He still drives daily and becomes angry when anyone suggests stopping. His daughter reports two recent minor collisions and says he is shopping for a new car this week. In clinic he refuses permission for you to discuss his condition with anyone outside the visit. You believe his impairment could make driving unsafe, but you also know that taking driving away would likely end his independence and damage his trust in care. Hospital risk management confirms that, in your state, either confidential counseling alone or clinician reporting to the licensing authority is legally permissible in this situation. You must decide before his imminent vehicle purchase and license renewal paperwork.
data.choice_1: File a medical report to the licensing authority recommending driving restrictions
data.choice_2: Keep confidentiality and limit intervention to counseling him to stop driving

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove language that implies medical certainty about unsafe driving. Edit “You believe his impairment could make driving unsafe” to a more neutral formulation such as “You are concerned his impairment may impair driving safety, but functional ability varies and you cannot determine his current driving competence from today’s visit alone.” Avoid implying one pathway is the clinically correct one.

key_information.suggested_changes: Tighten and add the missing functional/safety details needed to ground the dilemma while removing mildly extraneous items. Add: whether he has had any formal driving evaluation, visual/hearing status, and whether he uses sedating meds or has focal neuro deficits affecting driving. Consider removing/condensing “shopping for a new car this week” (keeping either the purchase OR renewal deadline is sufficient). Clarify what “moderate” means functionally (e.g., executive dysfunction, slowed processing) in 1 clause.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, two recent collisions plus “moderate dementia” makes reporting feel clearly favored, weakening genuine equipoise. To restore non-triviality, revise to make the risk signals ambiguous but concerning: e.g., “one minor collision and one near-miss reported by daughter,” or “scrapes in garage; unclear fault.” Alternatively, add countervailing evidence supporting continued driving (e.g., clean driving record until recently, drives only short familiar routes in daylight, daughter disagreement/possible secondary motives) and/or explicitly note uncertainty about his current driving competence and that mandated reporting is not required in this state.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance so Choice 2 is not obviously reckless given the two recent collisions. For example: (1) Clarify that the minor collisions had ambiguous fault (e.g., low-speed parking-lot scrapes, daughter uncertain whether he caused them), and that an in-clinic screen is equivocal (some deficits but still passes a basic road-safety screen), making unsafe driving a credible concern but not a near-certainty. (2) Add concrete, serious downsides to reporting: immediate automatic suspension before any on-road evaluation, high likelihood of social isolation because he lives alone in a car-dependent area with no viable transportation, and risk he will disengage from medical care or hide symptoms. (3) Strengthen the ethical ‘upside’ of counseling-only by adding a realistic safety plan (e.g., he agrees to limit driving to daylight/local trips, accept a formal on-road assessment within a short window, or allow follow-up/monitoring) so that confidentiality plus intensive intervention is defensible rather than passive non-action. (4) Remove or deemphasize ‘risk management confirms legality’ and instead state you know reporting is permitted but not required, to keep the dilemma ethical rather than legalistic.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize loaded wording that biases toward reporting: change “becomes angry” to “becomes upset/strongly objects,” remove “lost at home” or specify “misplacing items and occasional disorientation in unfamiliar settings,” and rephrase “taking driving away” to “driving cessation/restrictions.” Avoid implying the clinician’s view is clearly correct: change “could make driving unsafe” to “raises concern about driving safety.”

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify the forcing mechanism and clinical basis for concern. Specify whether there are objective functional deficits on exam (e.g., MoCA range, executive dysfunction) without numbers; otherwise remove “exam support” vagueness. Remove extraneous administrative detail (“license renewal paperwork”) or integrate it as the single forcing factor. Consider combining sentences about collisions and car purchase into one to reduce padding.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Shorten and standardize both choices to ~10–15 words and keep parallel structure. Example: Choice 1: “Report medically relevant impairment to the licensing authority for driving review.” Choice 2: “Do not report; provide counseling on driving cessation and document refusal.” Remove extra qualifiers like “recommending driving restrictions.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce the one-sidedness toward reporting created by “moderate dementia” plus “two recent collisions.” To rebalance, revise facts so driving risk is plausible but not clearly established (e.g., daughter reports near-misses or getting lost once, or collisions had clear alternative explanations like being rear-ended/ice/parking lot scrapes). Add a counterweight showing real, serious downside to reporting (e.g., in this state a clinician report triggers immediate automatic suspension and is shared with insurers/family court, likely ending his ability to attend dialysis/therapy and causing major deterioration). Also add something that makes counseling ethically weighty (e.g., he has consistently refused to stop but has capacity; he lives alone with no alternative transport, making loss of license predictably harmful).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: As written, there are obvious middle options (refer for an on-road driving evaluation/OT assessment, arrange urgent neuropsych testing, negotiate a time-limited driving restriction, schedule rapid follow-up, seek a family meeting, or involve the primary care clinician). To make it truly binary, explicitly rule these out with a realistic forcing constraint: e.g., the only driving assessment program has a months-long wait; he is leaving the area after this visit to purchase/register the car and submit renewal paperwork; he refuses any follow-up or testing; and the DMV in this state accepts only (a) physician report or (b) no report, with no provisional restrictions or expedited evaluations.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: The vignette risks being resolved by common professional advice that recent crashes plus cognitive impairment warrants reporting when permitted. To keep it in the gray zone, adjust clinical facts so guidelines/standards don’t clearly dictate one action: describe cognitive findings as mixed/borderline, functional impairment limited, capacity intact, and crash history ambiguous; and add a line that state medical society guidance is non-directive or variable (e.g., recommends individualized judgment and shared decision-making, with no clear threshold for reporting in moderate vascular dementia absent clear evidence of unsafe driving).

data.vignette: A 72-year-old man is evaluated for months of forgetfulness and occasional disorientation in unfamiliar places. Imaging and testing are consistent with subcortical vascular dementia with slowed processing and reduced executive function. He is independent with basic self-care and manages his bills, and he insists he is safe to drive. His daughter reports a recent low-speed parking-lot scrape and one episode of drifting within his lane; fault was unclear and no one was injured. He has no focal motor deficits, his vision is adequate with glasses, and he is not taking sedating medications. He refuses neuropsychologic testing, an on-road evaluation, follow-up before travel, or permission to contact family. He is leaving today to renew his license and register a car. In this state, physician reporting is permitted but not required, and either path is legally defensible. A clinician report here triggers automatic temporary suspension before any road test, which would likely isolate him in a car-dependent area and may end his engagement with care.
data.choice_1: Report his cognitive impairment to the licensing authority for driving review
data.choice_2: Do not report; counsel strict driving limits and document his plan
